cat__community_water_challenges_In my community, one of the biggest challenges is the limited availability of clean and safe drinking water. Many households rely on water delivered by trucks or collected from boreholes, which are often far away and sometimes contaminated. During the dry season, water becomes scarce, and prices rise, making it difficult for low-income families to afford. In some areas, water storage tanks are not properly maintained, leading to health risks such as waterborne diseases.
cat__community_water_challenges_High cost of water is very challenging in Juba

cat__additional_information_During the dry season, water becomes very scarce, and many people use untreated sources. Some areas have water that tastes salty or has a bad smell. Community awareness about water treatment and hygiene could help prevent diseases.

cat__additional_information_In some parts of Juba; particularly sherikat where I reside and some other parts that I have never been, people still depend on the Nile River for daily water use, which exposes them to unsafe water sources. Efforts to improve water infrastructure should also focus on educating the community about safe storage and treatment methods at home. With the right investment and community involvement, it is possible to make safe drinking water accessible and affordable for everyone in Juba.

cat__community_water_suggestions_As a South Sudanese who is concerned about the well-being of our communities, I believe improving access to safe drinking water in Juba requires a collective and sustainable approach. First, we must invest in water purification system and protect existing water sources from contamination. The government in partnership with NGOs and international donars, should prioritize building and maintaining clean water infrastructure such as boreholes, protected well, and treatment facilities. Community education hygiene and safe water storage is also vital. Lastly, empowering local water committees to manage resources transparently will ensure long-term impact and ownership. Access to clean water is not a luxury its a right.

cat__community_water_suggestions_To improve access, the government and NGOs could invest in expanding the piped water network to reach more neighborhoods. Regular water quality testing and public awareness campaigns about water hygiene would also help prevent disease. Installing more community boreholes and providing affordable water purification systems, such as filters or chlorine tablets, could make a big difference. Additionally, better regulation of private water suppliers would ensure the water sold to the public meets safety standards.
